description:
Lateolabrax maculatus, also known as the spotted sea bass, is a species of marine fish belonging to the family Moronidae. It is native to the western Pacific Ocean, found along the coasts of China, Korea, and Japan.

The spotted sea bass is a predatory fish that typically grows to a length of around 40-60 cm. It has an elongated, streamlined body with a large, slightly protruding mouth. The fish is characterized by its distinctive spotted pattern, with dark spots or blotches covering its body and fins.

Lateolabrax maculatus is an important commercial and recreational fish species in its native range, valued for its firm, white flesh and mild flavor. It inhabits coastal waters, often found near rocky reefs, kelp beds, and estuaries, where it feeds on a variety of small fishes, crustaceans, and mollusks.

The species plays a significant role in the ecosystem, serving as both a predator and prey within the marine food web. It is considered an ecologically important component of the coastal ecosystems it inhabits.
